title: How to Set up a Network in Ubuntu

steps.title: Open Network Connections to set up network settings in Ubuntu.
steps.content: Open Network Connections to set up network settings in Ubuntu. Go to “System”, “Preferences” and chose “Network Connections."

steps.title: Under the “Wired” tab, click on “Auto eth0” and select “Edit."
steps.content: Under the “Wired” tab, click on “Auto eth0” and select “Edit."

steps.title: Click on “IPV4 Settings” tab.
steps.content: Click on “IPV4 Settings” tab. Chose the “Automatic (DHCP)” option if your network has a DHCP server. The DHCP Server has automatically assigned the IP address to your system. Click "Apply." You also chose the “Manual” option from the Method drop-down list and assign the IP address, netmask and gateway manually. You'll also have to assign the DNS Server address. Click "Apply."

steps.title: Check the IP address settings.
steps.content: Check the IP address settings. Go to “Applications” “Accessories” and chose “Terminal."

steps.title: Type the following command into terminal:
steps.content: Type the following command into terminal: “sudo ifconfig” without quotes.

steps.title: Get your new addresses.
steps.content: Get your new addresses. The Ifconfig command will show the inet address, broadcast address and mask address.
